ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

FITNESS OF RESERVISTS


    1. Encik Abbas Abu Amin asked the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence what his Ministry has done to improve the fitness of reservists,

    The Minister of State for Defence and Trade and Industry (BG Lee Hsien Loong) (for the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence): Mr Speaker, Sir, keeping fit is the reservists' own responsibility. Mindef can only check on how well they are doing it. An unfit soldier is a danger to himself and a liability to his unit. He will not last in war.

    Mindef tests the physical fitness of reservists by requiring them to take the Individual Physical Proficiency Test (IPPT) every six months. The passing rate over the past three years has been 90%, creditable but not good enough.

    Beginning from January, 1984, reservists who pass particularly well need take their next IPPT only 12 months later. That means those who do well, take it once a year; those who do not do so well, take it twice a year. Mindef can be confident that the ones who do well do not just practise for a few weeks to pass the test, but know how to keep fit throughout the year. About one-third of the reservists are achieving this. Also, the 8% who score outstanding results are awarded certificates of merit. These moves encourage -reservists to develop keep-fit habits.

    Reservists who achieve only the minimum standards will continue to take the IPPT twice a year. Persistent failures have to attend Residential Training in Pulau Tekong for seven days, in addition to their normal in-camp training. Residential training is a draconian physical fitness regime. It is meant to deter slackening, and to teach reservists the importance of keeping fit at all times. In 1983, about 9,600 reservists went through residential training. In 1984, the number dropped to about 5,500. It appears that reservists are taking the IPPT more seriously.

    To help reservists keep themselves fit, Mindef has installed 23 sets of keep-fit

Column: 988

apparatus at community centres, sports complexes, and fitness parks; organizes keep-fit classes for reservists and members of the public at 12 selected community centres; and conducts Basic and Advanced Physical Fitness Courses for volunteer youth leaders in community centres, who will subsequently organize physical fitness activities on their own. In addition, the Singapore Armed Forces Reservists' Association (SAFRA) runs a health club at the Bukit Merah SAFRA Clubhouse.

    A public opinion survey late last year found that about 30% of Singaporeans doubted the physical fitness of reservists, nearly one-third. The young were even more doubtful. Half of those aged 27 and below, many of whom would have been reservists themselves, were not satisfied with reservist fitness standards. Probably the standards they had in mind were higher. It is clear that the reservists themselves will have to convince the public that they are physically fit.

     Encik Abbas Abu Amin (Pasir Panjang): Sir, could the Minister of State clarify on the obese situation in the SAF, and what remedial actions are being taken to further improve the physical fitness of these affected personnel?

     BG Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, when we talk about obese people, the people who are overweight, there are two groups. There is a group who are overweight while doing their full-time national service, aged 18 and 19. They are put through a more gradual form of basic military training to bring them up to their full physical potential. But, eventually, they must reach that physical standard. Then there is the question of reservists who have become obese a number of years after active national service. I think the second category is, in the long term, a more serious problem, because the reservists really have to solve this problem themselves. We can ensure that it becomes uncomfortable for them to remain unfit, by making sure that they take the physical fitness test twice a year, by making sure that they pass, and if they do not pass, we bring them to Pulau Tekong. I think those Members who have had

Column: 989

reservists come to them at Meet-the-People sessions, begging not to go to Pulau Tekong, will understand what is in store for these reservists.

ACCORD
(Progress)


    2. Encik Abbas Abu Amin asked the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence what is the progress made by ACCORD, which was set up in 1984 to provide measures through which the public can be persuaded and educated to give support and recognition to National Servicemen.

     BG Lee Hsien Loong (for the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Advisory Council on Community Relations in Defence (better known as ACCORD) reviews and suggests improvements to current and new Mindef policies which affect the community at large.

    Although ACCORD members serve in their personal capacities, they give good feedback because they come from a wide cross-section of the population. Among them are Members of Parliament, businessmen, school principals, community leaders, SAF reservists, a trade unionist, a journalist, a lawyer, a surgeon, the present President of Nanyang Technological Institute and the Director of VITB.

    ACCORD's terms of reference are much wider than to foster public support and recognition just for national servicemen. ACCORD's role is to review and recommend measures to increase support and recognition for full-time national servicemen and reservists by the public, their families, employers and peers, and to create awareness and understanding among the general public of their role in the Total Defence of the country.

    The following are some of the suggestions ACCORD has made. In preparation for National Service, ACCORD has suggested that Mindef should speak to the Ministry of Education and the schools on the importance of preparing schoolboys, both physically and psychologically, for

Column: 990

National Service. Some areas which should be studied are: how to improve the physical education and swimming programme in schools; how to identify early, and treat, where possible, children who have poor eyesight; and how to educate students on Total Defence and the role of the SAF, through the school curriculum.

    Another area is civil resource mobilization. ACCORD has suggested that the SAF should test out mobilization procedures, internally first, so as to minimize inconvenience to the public. Also, that Mindef should meet owners and operators of the civil resources to receive their comments and suggestions before finalizing the regulations and mechanics for mobilization.

    On Open Mobilization of reservists, ACCORD has suggested that Mindef should give the public ample warning, so that they will not be alarmed by the Open Mobilization exercises. As Members would be aware from my answer yesterday, this is precisely what Mindef is doing.

    On Total Defence promotional activities, ACCORD has suggested that, in addition to advertising and presentations to various interested groups, Mindef should also reach out to school children, for example, by distributing song sheets and cassette tapes of the Total Defence song "There's a Part for Everyone".

    On employer involvement, ACCORD has suggested that Mindef should consider giving awards to employers who have enlightened personnel policies on reserve service.

ADVERTISING PROGRAMME OF MINDEF
(Particulars)


    3. Mr S. Chandra Das asked the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence (a) how much was spent on the advertising programme of the Defence Ministry; (b) whether MINDEF has gained through its advertising; and (c) whether the public understand Total Defence better.

     BG Lee Hsien Loong (for the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence): Mr Speaker, Sir, Mindef spent $3

Column: 991

million on advertising last year. $1 million was spent on Total Defence advertising, and $2 million on recruitment advertising.

    Advertising in newspapers and on television is one very visible way for Mindef to educate the public about the SAF, about the importance of defence, and about how citizens can contribute to national security. Singaporeans must know what the SAF is doing, they must identify with the SAF, and they must be proud of the SAF. This did not use to be the case, but increasingly it is, partly because of our advertising.

    Mindef commissioned a public opinion survey late last year. The results showed various percentages of Singaporeans who believed that:

    (1) we can discourage others from attacking us if we are serious about Total Defence - 74%.

    (2) SAF training produces good soldiers - 82%.

    (3) reservists are ready to fight at any time - 78%.

    (4) the SAF is a modern fighting force - 73%.

    (5) SAF officers are good leaders - 72%.

    (6) full-time National Service is essential for our defence - 96%, nearly every Singaporean.

    However, the survey also showed that there are some groups who still know little about the SAF and defence matters. Such people include about one-quarter of Singaporeans, more than 45 years old, and one-third of housewives, Furthermore, only half the population understand that SAF reservists are not only the largest part of our fighting force, but are also front-line soldiers, who will go into combat simultaneously with the regulars and full-time national servicemen, In other words, there is still the general belief that reservists are what you say in Mandarin (    ), ie, after the regulars have fought, after the full-time national servicemen have fought, then you call up the reservists. This is completely wrong. Clearly, the general public needs to be further educated on the front-line role of reservists.

Column: 992



    Mindef's public communication objectives for this year are:

    (a) to show particular groups, such as parents, teachers, employers, and senior citizens, how they can participate in Total Defence;

    (b) to make the public aware that SAF reservists are front-line soldiers who will go into battle at the same time as regulars and full-time national servicemen; and

    (c) to improve public knowledge of the SAF.

    Advertising will be used again as appropriate.

     Mr S. Chandra Das (Chong Boon): Sir, I would like to ask the Minister of State what are Mindef's long-term plans in bringing this message of Total Defence to the people at large.

     BG Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, our Total Defence message last year was "Total Defence, because a generation's effort can be wiped out in days." That is the first thing which Singaporeans have to understand. As we go along, we plan to involve people in more and more concrete ways to do things connected with Total Defence. So they know what is their role, what is their contribution, what is expected of them. Housewives have to learn civil defence drills, learn first-aid, learn what happens if the building is damaged, learn how to cope with your neighbours. Employers have to learn, and we better educate them, how they can participate if civil resources are mobilized. As you are aware, Mr Speaker, Sir, there is legislation which is currently before the House. School children must be educated on how to grow up, so that ideas of Total Defence, so that consciousness of national security, is second nature to them, so that they do not grow up having a cold, intellectual debate about whether or not it is worth defending this country. They grow up believing, as an axiom of faith, that this is a country which is worth defending, and which they shall defend. That is our longterm plan for Total Defence education in Singapore.

     Dr Arthur Beng Kian Lam (Fengshan): Sir, is the Minister of State satisfied

Column: 993

that the $2 million spent on recruitment advertisement has been cost-effective?

     BG Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, $2 million spent on recruitment advertising has to be compared, firstly, to the amount of money which we have to spend on salaries and on wages, and allowances for our manpower, which comes to about $600 million a year. So that is about one-third of a per cent. It is a very small proportion. It is worthwhile, not only for the bodies which it brings in to us, but also for the general education which it provides to the population. Because when you see an advertisement in the Straits Times or in the Zaobao or on television, it is not only the person who cuts out the little box who is affected, but everybody who sees it says yes, the SAF is an outfit which we can be proud of. And from that point of view, also, it has been extremely cost-effective.

ABUSE OF VOLATILE INHALANTS
(Measures to curb)


    7. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Second Minister for Law (a) if he will enlighten the House on the problem of glue-sniffing by youths, particularly in the schools; (b) what measures are being taken to discourage them from such practice; (c) whether there are programmes to rehabilitate youths with such addiction; and (d) whether the situation is under control,

Column: 995



     Mr Wong Kan Seng (for the Minister for Home Affairs and Second Minister for Law): Mr Speaker, Sir, the abuse of volatile inhalants, commonly known as glue sniffing, was first detected in Singapore in 1980. The number of cases detected had increased from 24 in 1980 to 820 in 1983 and 812 cases in 1984.

    The inhalant abuse problem is therefore increasing and is a cause for concern, although it has not reached epidemic proportions. This explains why the Singapore Anti-Narcotics Association has launched a three-month island-wide campaign on llth March 1985 to inform the public, especially the parents, on the dangers and evils of inhalant abuse.

    Although the abusers are not physically addicted, the increasing number of repeaters arrested shows that some of them had developed psychological dependence on inhalants. Long-term inhalant abuse leads to permanent and irreversible damage to the brain, liver and kidneys.

    A study of the abusers detected from 1980 to 1984 shows that 88.7% are under 20 years of age, 20.5% of them are below 15 years old and 68.2% of them between the ages of 15 and 19. The majority of these inhalant abusers are school dropouts. The number of inhalant abuse cases who were school children detected in 1982, 1983 and 1984 were 54, 133 and 128 respectively,

    Measures taken to curb the problem of inhalant abuse are as follows:

    (a) Abusers who are school pupils are referred to the Guidance and Social Work Unit of the Ministry of Education for counselling and guidance.

    (b) Abusers who are below 16 years of age and not schooling are referred to the Children and Youth Services of the Ministry of Community Development for counselling. They are also encouraged to join the Boys' Clubs so that they can take part in organized activities. Chronic abusers, ie, the repeaters, who are beyond parental control, are dealt with by the Juvenile Court under the Children and Young Persons Act. They may be placed by the Court in an approved home or on probation for care and protection.

Column: 996



    (c) lnhalant abusers who are above 16 years old and not schooling are warned, together with their parents, of the dangers of inhalant abuse. Offenders with drug records are referred to the Drug Rehabilitation Centre for medical examination and observation to determine if they had relapsed to drug consumption. Habitual offenders are placed on voluntary supervision by enforcement officers.

    (d) lnhalant abusers who are mentally affected by the inhalants are referred to the Woodbridge Hospital for psychiatric examination. Bad cases are warded for treatment.

    An Anti-inhalant Abuse Coordination Committee comprising representatives from my Ministry, the Ministry of Education, the Ministry of Community Development, the Ministry of Health, SANA, SAF and Scientific Services Department, has been set up to monitor and plan strategies to solve this problem. An anti-inhalant abuse team has also been formed in the Central Narcotics Bureau to monitor all detected cases and to assist the Coordination Committee in formulating and implementing plans to curb the spread of inhalant abuse. If preventive, educative and counselling measures prove inadequate, we will consider further measures including, if necessary, legislation requiring offenders to undergo treatment and rehabilitation.

     Mr Abdullah Tarmugi (Siglap): Mr Speaker, Sir, given the easy availability of inhalants to the public, does the Ministry have any long-term plans to tackle this problem of easy supply?

     Mr Wong Kan Seng:. Sir, as I mentioned, there is already a Coordination Committee comprising representatives from multi-Ministries as well as an anti-inhalant abuse team in the CNB to deal with this problem. I would say that if the measures I described earlier are not adequate to deal with the problem, then we will consider other measures, including legislation.

    It is not easy to stop someone from buying a can of glue or other inhalants. These things are freely and readily available in homes, factories and shops. So it is not practical to consider banning

Column: 997

the use of such items which may lead to inhalant abuse.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have two supplementary questions. First, is the question of counsellors. Can the Minister of State for Home Affairs and Community Development enlighten this House on what form of training do counsellors get? The second question is whether these counsellors are adequately trained, and how do they go about counselling the addicts?

     Mr Wong Kan Seng: Mr Speaker, Sir, the inhalant abusers, who are referred to the Guidance Social Work Unit of the Ministry of Education, I believe, are counselled by professional counsellors. They are educationists as well. As for the abusers who are referred to the Ministry of Community Development, they are counselled by social workers trained in the art of counselling. So they are all professionals.

    There is no other body other than these two which counsel inhalant abusers.

HDB NEW ACCOUNTING SYSTEM
(Statement by the Minister
for National Development)

11.24am

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I wish to make a statement on the new accounting system for the Housing and Development Board. The Housing and Development Board's existing accounting system has been used for over two decades. This system was inherited from the former Singapore Improvement Trust (SIT). The SIT system was a system used by most of the United Kingdom's local authorities. It was adequate in the early years when the HDB's main function was to provide low-cost housing for rental. Over the years, the HDB's major activity has shifted from rental of flats to the sale of flats.

    For the past few years, the Auditor-General in auditing the HDB's accounts has stated that the HDB accounting system did not provide for the costing of flats. This means the sale proceeds could not be matched against the cost. As a result, the HDB's accounts do not show adequately the entire operations of the Board. The HDB on its part increasingly feels the need to have a modern integrated computerized accounting system to replace the present manually operated one. The HDB's activities affect almost every family in Singapore. At the end of 1984, almost 81% of the population live in HDB housing. Three-quarters of these HDB dwellers live in purchase flats, while the remaining quarter are tenants of rental flats.

    In addition to managing half a million dwelling units, the HDB owns and manages factories, shops, hawker stalls, offices and parking lots. The number of accounts handled by the HDB exceeds one million, comprising 479,000 service and conservancy accounts, 216,000 loan and instalment repayment accounts, 137,000 rental accounts and thousands of hawkers' accounts, parking accounts, etc.

    In response to the Auditor-General's comment and to meet its own needs, the HDB embarked on plans to change its accounting system in early 1982. A committee comprising the Auditor-General,

Column: 999

the Accountant-General and representatives from the Ministries of Finance and National Development and the HDB was formed to oversee the change of accounting system. In April 1983, the committee selected the international accounting firm of Price Waterhouse as the consultant for the design of fully integrated and computerized accounting system for the HDB.

    The new system of accounts has since been designed and tested. The new accounting system has been accepted by the Auditor-General, Accountant-General and the Ministry of Finance. As I have informed the House on 15th March 1984, the new system will be implemented from 1st April this year.

    The existing presentation of accounts will be replaced by the new format of balance sheet and income and expenditure presentation. The accounts will be drawn up on the basis of cost centres. It will enable the operating results of specific activities to be reflected separately. Thus, the sale of flats, rental of flats and service and conservancy operations will constitute distinct cost centres besides others like car parking operations, hawker/market operations and so on.

    The fundamental shortcoming of the existing system is that the cost of the flat is not reflected in the accounts. Currently, besides annual subsidies provided by Government for HDB operations, the Government has been subsidizing public housing through the provision of cheap State Land. In some cases, land inherited from SIT was at no cost to HDB. In order that the new accounting system will fully reflect the true economic cost of flats, the HDB will return all its undeveloped land stock back to the Government at cost before 1st April, 1985. As and when land is required in future for public housing and related facilities, the HDB will buy the required land from the Government at current market value for similar private residential land. Thus the true current economic cost of flats, both of land and construction cost, will be clearly reflected in the HDB accounts.

    The Government will continue to subsidize any deficits incurred by HDB arising from selling public housing below their

Column: 1000

cost. With Government subsidies, prices of HDB flats under the new accounting system are expected to be similar to those under the old accounting system.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: Mr Speaker, Sir, may I ask of the hon. Minister two questions arising from his Ministerial Statement. First, what was the cost involved in getting the consultant to evolve the new kind of accounting system for the HDB? In other words, the consultation fee and the amount involved in this whole exercise. Secondly, with the prospect of having to buy back land from the Government after lst April this year, may I ask of the Minister whether land will be bought back as encumbered land or land with vacant possession?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am sorry I do not have the details of the fees paid or to be paid to the consultant, plus the HDB's own cost. It is a fully computerized system and as it involves a lot of hardware and software, I would not be able to give the answer now. But I will give the hon. Member the details of the costing in writing.

    On the question of the land cost, it does not really make much difference whether HDB buys the land from the Government either as vacant land or encumbered land. If it is vacant land, then the land value will be valued at the vacant land value. If it is encumbered land, then the value will be much lower, because resettlement costs will be involved. Therefore, HDB will be able to buy the land from the Government at a lower price.

     Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam (Anson): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I ask the Minister what is the purpose or object behind this exercise of the HDB selling land back to the Government, the land which it already has, and then buying ii back from the Government. Is it to push up the prices of HDB flats or to justify their sale prices?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, as I have stated in my statement, this is to achieve correct accounting for the pricing of the HDB flats. As I have mentioned earlier, previously HDB flats were built on SIT land. In fact, there was no land cost involved, which means that HDB was

Column: 1001
